children.subject:
dual-mode refers to a flexible format, meaning you have the option to attend in-person. I have updated the language in the post to mirror the language used in the instruction FAQS. 

Yes, your example makes sense

Based on the link for definitions, 'Dual-mode', does this mean we can pick between in person or online for different parts of the course?

Eg. I can do lecture online, discussion in person, and lab online, but my friend can do lecture online, discussion online, and lab in person?

Just trying to make sense of it! Thanks!
No idea, contact Berkeley International Office to make sure.
Any idea whether dual-mode classes would count towards the in-person class requirement for international students?
I would treat that as online instead of in person unless someone like admin or course staff say otherwise
On the course catalog, 162 says it'll be in-person, but the location is remote... what does that mean?

It means that literally we are going too fast & I cannot keep up with making changes in the system!

The INTENT is for remote lecture with some amount of secondary sections available in-person but we are still not able to book rooms yet so we can't say how many sections there will be, how many students can be in those sections or where they will be located. Please be patient and recognize that we likely won't be able to offer updated information in the system until phase 2.
We are still working out those details, seems like there could be in-person debugging sessions. We will updated all students enrolled or on the waitlist when we have more information.
Does requested flexible labs mean you can attend EECS 16B in person?
Eventually, yes. The key word is EVENTUALLY. Everything is moving so fast and these are new fields in the system. I literally have over 3,000 records to update while working on other things too.
For the CS classes which are expected to offer in-person sections, does that mean they will be updated to be listed as flexible classes?
Yes, but again, I need to coordinate with teaching staff. I will expand the class and update the format info as I have it in a day or so.
Is there any update regarding this?
I just expanded the class to 700 seats.
Does CS170 plan to expand any more than 700 seats? I am at the end of the waitlist and was wondering if I had any chance of getting in the class.
As far as I know right now, this class will not expand further.
On a somewhat unrelated note, is CS170 expanding beyond its current 300-person capacity?
We are doing our best - this is in process. Please be patient while we work everything out.
CS61B DIS in the course catalog now says ' Flex--See class note details'. Does this mean it is confirmed that atleast some discussions will be in person?

These are in process, please be patient. Just because we've requested this doesn't mean it will actually work out. As soon as I know something, I will post in Piazza & update class notes for all classes in this circumstance.

Thank you for all that you are doing! I was curious because 61C was not mentioned in this Piazza post of classes that were being requested for in-person sections but the course catalog suggested otherwise.

The current delay is actually around getting approval to re-open Soda Hall for instruction. The building manager is working hard to get information to campus for approval but the review committee has to do this work for every building with classrooms on campus.

I know it's challenging to be patient, but this is the most complex logistical undertaking most faculty/staff have ever faced - and we're working to resolve multiple issues in a very short amount of time.

Ultimately what is most important is keeping everyone as safe as possible while facilitating learning as best as we know how to do.
Has 61C also been submitted for review for a few in-person discussion sections? On the course catalog it says "Instruction Mode: Flex--See class note details" under COMPSCI 61C 999.

199 and 299 courses are all marked as hybrid classes. You will not be able to find them in the course catalog. 


For 199s, follow the instructions for receiving 199 research credit on this page and a CN will be sent to you: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/research

For 299s, grad students should see the list on this page: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/grads/classes-scheduling

Thanks! I will be trying to enroll into EE299, with permission of my advisor. I am however running into an "Unauthorized" issue when I click on "EE Fall or Spring" under 299 Class Numbers - is this normal?

You should be able to access that page if you are an EECS/CS grad student. Sounds like you may need your permission updated, contact your grad advisor for assistance:

For CS doctoral students: Jean Nguyen

For EE doctoral students: Shirley Salanio

For masters students:  Michael Sun

What is the status on 199/299 courses for next semester? I can't find them on the course catalog. I'm mostly wondering because the new guidance we received from the International Office today says:

"All 99, 194H, 199, 298, and 299 courses (count as in-person courses for immigration purposes) as long as they are coded as In-person, Hybrid or Flexible instructional modes"

It would be particularly helpful for international students if research units could potentially be coded one of those ways.

16B has submitted a request for a flexible mode of instruction. If approved, the class will be updated to flexible.

BIO said that so long as a class is labeled as in-person, hybrid, or flexible, it would count as in-person class for immigration purposes.
Thank you Mayra! This update provided us with some much needed assurance right now. Also I am wondering is there any expected timeline for the decision to be ultimately made?

For courses like EECS 16B, which as stated in the op is requesting for in-person labs and so far our class still list the lab with a physical location (cory 125). Will classes like EECS 16B be treated as hybrid/flexible in terms of instruction mode? (This is really important to us now given the recent International Office update on the new ICE rules) Thanks!
For CS 186 that is correct. The instructors never made provision for, nor requested approval to offer in-person components for this class. Their intention is remote-only all semester long.

For classes that are "Remote Instruction" (EE16B and CS186) is there a nonzero probability that they may change to in person discussion/OH if the situation gets better in October (for example). Or are they committed to being 100% remote regardless?

I cannot say at this point. Even though we do not have to deal with room constraints when courses are offered remotely, we do still have to deal with budget/hiring constraints to have enough GSIs to support the course. If this class expands further, it's not likely to happen until closer to the start of the semester.

Are you going to expand CS61B? I can’t add this class until adjustment period, I saw there are 1800+ spots on the spring 2020, for the fall 2020, if I add this class in the adjustment period, can I get into the class? Thank you
All CompSci courses fell into the Tier 3 category.

The latest major announcement from campus makes a distinction between Tier 1, Tier 2, and Tier 3 courses and says that it is less likely that Tier 3 in-person instructional activities will be offered, even later in the semester. What tier does discussion sections for classes like CS 170 or CS 61C fit into?
You need to enrol through Data 100, not compsci c100. Unless you're a stats/ds major you'll be waitlisted, but I expect you to get in if you get on the waitlist right now
<md>Thank you :) I got in. Also, does it count as a Tech Elective if I am not mistaken?</md>
It counts as a cs upper div, if that's what you're asking
<md>Sorry it's late but is there a way that I can enroll in COMPSCI 100? I saw that the class is closed but I was wondering if there is a possibility of expansion.</md>

There are no guarantees when it comes to enrollments but your odds of getting in are very, very good.

Enrollment fluctuates from semester to semester & it can be easier to get in some semesters than others. You can see the trends by searching berkeleytime.com.

Am I guaranteed a spot for CS189 if there are only two people on the waitlist? I'm confused because I heard this class is really hard to get into but the waitlist doesn't seem bad at all. Also I need this class to graduate this semester.

history.content:
Recently the Registrar notified all continuing undergraduate and graduate students that an additional brief enrollment phase will open on July 8th to allow students to make changes to phase 1 course selections if needed.

 

The following information is from the Registrar’s website regarding this enrollment phase:

  • The appointment window will be assigned and appear as Phase 1.5 in CalCentral beginning on Sunday, July 5. Times are listed in Pacific Daylight Time (PDT)

  • Undergraduate appointments will begin on July 8 and 9 and end July 11 at 11:59PM. Appointments are assigned based on terms in attendance for undergraduates.

  • Graduate appointments will begin on July 10 and end on July 13 at 11:59PM.  

  • No priority enrollment appointments will apply. 

  • The Phase 1 Enrollment limit of 13.5 (including waitlist) for undergraduates and 12 (including waitlist) for graduates still apply. 

  • See the Instruction FAQ for more detailed information on enrollment.

 

As you prepare for phase 1.5, you will notice new information appears in CalCentral and classes.berkeley.edu regarding the teaching format for the lecture and any associated sections.

To learn more about the specific terminology used, please read this list of definitions.

 

Within EECS and CompSci, the majority of classes will be held remote only. Be aware for classes using 999 sections, that the majority of meeting days/times for any synchronous lab and/or discussion section is pending review and subject to change. Be sure to check out the CLASS NOTES associated with the class in classes.berkeley.edu to learn if synchronous section times are confirmed or not.

 

As of July 7th, we are still waiting for Campus to review/approve our requests for the following classes to offer some in-person components. These classes will be updated on an on-going basis. 

 

EE/EECS

  • EE 84-002 - flexible mode
  • EE 105 - remote only (possibility of in-person labs if in-person resumes)
  • EE 140/240A - requested flexible mode 
  • EE 143 - provisionally approved for flexible sections 
  • EE 147/247A - flexible lecture, discussions will be remote only
  • EE 290-004 with Professor Arcak - flexible mode
  • EECS 16B - remote only
  • EECS 126 - requested flexible mode (for 2 discussion sections)
  • EECS 149/ EE C249A / CS C249A - provisionally approved for hybrid
  • EECS C106A/206A - provisionally approved for flexible labs (lecture will be online only)
  • EECS 16A - requested flexible mode (for discussions - exact number unknown)

 

CompSci - we are awaiting approval from the review committee to offer the following:

  • CS 24-003 - requested hybrid
  • CS 61B - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 70 - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 88 - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 162 - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 169A - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 170 - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 194-015 - hybrid mode
  • CS 294-082 - hybrid mode
  • CS 294-153 - hybrid mode
  • CS 294-165 - hybrid mode

 

All EE/CS 199/299 have been updated to hybrid/flexible mode of instruction.

Note that even though these classes may be approved for formats other than remote, they can go remote at any time in accordance with public health guidelines.

As more information becomes available, we will update this post as well as the class notes.

 

In the meantime, you may find this list of additional resources helpful:

If you need to speak with an advisor: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/advising or https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/grads/advisors

 

For enrollment FAQs, see:

https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

 

To see EECS enrollment policies, visit: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy and https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/getting-into-ee-classes

If you need assistance with an enrollment-related issue for F20, please email: cs-enrollments@berkeley.edu or ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu

  • The appointment window will be assigned and appear as Phase 1.5 in CalCentral beginning on Sunday, July 5. Times are listed in Pacific Daylight Time (PDT)

  • Undergraduate appointments will begin on July 8 and 9 and end July 11 at 11:59PM. Appointments are assigned based on terms in attendance for undergraduates.

  • Graduate appointments will begin on July 10 and end on July 13 at 11:59PM.  

  • No priority enrollment appointments will apply. 

  • The Phase 1 Enrollment limit of 13.5 (including waitlist) for undergraduates and 12 (including waitlist) for graduates still apply. 

  • See the Instruction FAQ for more detailed information on enrollment.

 

As you prepare for phase 1.5, you will notice new information appears in CalCentral and classes.berkeley.edu regarding the teaching format for the lecture and any associated sections.

To learn more about the specific terminology used, please read this list of definitions.

 

Within EECS and CompSci, the majority of classes will be held remote only. Be aware for classes using 999 sections, that the majority of meeting days/times for any synchronous lab and/or discussion section is pending review and subject to change. Be sure to check out the CLASS NOTES associated with the class in classes.berkeley.edu to learn if synchronous section times are confirmed or not.

 

As of July 7th, we are still waiting for Campus to review/approve our requests for the following classes to offer some in-person components. These classes will be updated on an on-going basis. 

 

EE/EECS

  • EE 84-002 - provisionally approved for flexible mode
  • EE 105 - requested for flexible sections
  • EE 140/240A - requested flexible mode
  • EE 143 - provisionally approved for flexible sections
  • EE 147/247A - requested flexible mode
  • EE 290-004 with Professor Arcak - requested flexible mode
  • EE 290-006 with Professor Yablonovitch - requested flexible mode
  • EECS 16B - requested flexible labs
  • EECS 149/ EE C249A / CS C249A - provisionally approved for hybrid
  • EECS C106A/206A - provisionally approved for flexible sections

 

CompSci - we are awaiting approval from the review committee to offer the following:

  • CS 61B - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 70 - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 88 - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 162 - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 169A - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 170 - a few in-person sections (exact number unknown)
  • CS 194-015 - hybrid mode
  • CS 294-082 - hybrid mode
  • CS 294-153 - hybrid mode
  • CS 294-165 - hybrid mode

 

Note that even though these classes may be approved for formats other than remote, they can go remote at any time in accordance with public health guidelines.

 

As more information becomes available, we will update this post as well as the class notes.

 

In the meantime, you may find this list of additional resources helpful

If you need to speak with an advisor: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/advising or https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/grads/advisors

 

For enrollment FAQs, see:

https://sis.berkeley.edu/help/enrollment-faq

 

To see EECS enrollment policies, visit: https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/cs/degree-reqs/enrollment-policy and https://eecs.berkeley.edu/resources/undergrads/getting-into-ee-classes

If you need assistance with an enrollment-related issue for F20, please email: cs-enrollments@berkeley.edu or ee-scheduling@eecs.berkeley.edu
